messages.subject: Re: akasaka vs akao
messages.msgSnippet: I ve seen Akasaka tsuba signed Bushu ju ..... and Akao signed Echizen ju ..... So I assume they were working in different regions??? Also the Akao tsuba that
messages.messageBody:
I've seen Akasaka tsuba signed Bushu ju .....
and Akao signed Echizen ju .....

So I assume they were working in different regions???
Also the Akao tsuba that I've seen don't have the tapering
top seppa dai that is found on many Akasaka works.

Hopefully someone with more knowledge than I can comment
on differences.

Rich S
------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm
------------------------------------------------------------

messages.subject: akasaka vs akao
messages.msgSnippet: Gang, I am a bit miffed / confused. Could someone please explain what the obvious differences are between akasaka and akao tsuba ? I am lost and trying to find
messages.messageBody:
Gang,

I am a bit miffed / confused. Could someone please explain what the
obvious differences are between akasaka and akao tsuba ? I am lost and
trying to find my path !

thanks, Matt

Ps. Curran, I know the frog jumping out of the pond story from my
Chinese art studies, that is where it originally came from.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Unusual Frog / Toad Menuki
messages.msgSnippet: Doug- Ono-no-tofu. Big thanks. The second story actually fits with the tsuba I saw. The frog is in motion across the tsuba towards or up an incline. The
messages.messageBody:
Doug-

Ono-no-tofu. Big thanks.
The second story actually fits with the tsuba I
saw. The frog is in motion across the tsuba towards or
up an incline. The smiling man overlooking the frog is
positioned in the background, with the incline
covering part of his legs. He's obviously watching the
frog.

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Unusual Frog / Toad Menuki
messages.msgSnippet: There are two stories where frogs (or toads) crop up, that I know of, in Japanese imagery.  One is with Gama Senin- a mythical sage who is often seen with a
messages.messageBody:
There are two stories where frogs (or toads) crop up, that I know of, in Japanese imagery. One is
with Gama Senin- a mythical sage who is often seen with a toad on his shoulder. Sort of his
familiar.
The other is the story of Ono-no-tofu, whereby a would-be civil servant is encouraged to try once
again at taking his exams after watching a frog perservere in his attempts to jump out of a pond,
up a steep bank. A frog could therefore be seen as a symbol of perserverance.


-Doug Sanders
> At the same time I saw these two odd-guys, I saw a
> tsuba with another stylized frog / toad wearing a
> similar quirked expression. An wise man or priest was
> standing in the backgound overlooking the frog with a
> jovial look on his face.
> I did no know if there was a story here. Other than
> Kermit, I'm not too fond of frogs.
>
> Curran
>
>
>
> --- Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:
> > Curran,
> > For what it's worth I used to have a pair of menuki
> > in exactly that "pose" that were signed on the edge
> > Yoshioka Inabanosuke. They were better quality than
> > these appear to be, and were not what I'd think of
> > as typical Yoshioka group work. It can be tough to
> > attribute a lot of the unsigned later menuki to a
> > specific group.
> >
> > Jim
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > Groups-
> >
> > Came across these unusual menuki. Figured it might
> > interest some others.
> >
> > http://www.l-wise.co.jp/sword/sdata24/clk259b.htm
> >
> > Any chance anyone can attribute this ugly duo to
> > any
> > specific school? I'm assuming they are late late
> > Edo
> > or Meiji.
> >
> > Curran
> >

messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 12/20/2003 8:53:34 PM Central Standard Time, matthewhoyle@wanadoo.nl writes: How can you tell whether it is a frog or a toad ? I always
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 12/20/2003 8:53:34 PM Central Standard Time,
matthewhoyle@... writes:
How can you tell whether it is a frog or a toad ?

I always wondered about that !! hahaha

Matt
if the frog has pimples then it's a toad..........
besides the site identifies it as " ha-mo " which means toad in chinese.

Milt

Van: Curran Campbell [mailto:neobliviscar@...]
Verzonden: zondag 21 december 2003 3:48
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Unusual Frog / Toad Menuki


Jim-

Thanks for the reply. I was just curious.
At the same time I saw these two odd-guys, I saw a
tsuba with another stylized frog / toad wearing a
similar quirked expression. An wise man or priest was
standing in the backgound overlooking the frog with a
jovial look on his face.
I did no know if there was a story here. Other than
Kermit, I'm not too fond of frogs.

Curran



--- Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:
> Curran,
> For what it's worth I used to have a pair of menuki
> in exactly that "pose" that were signed on the edge
> Yoshioka Inabanosuke. They were better quality than
> these appear to be, and were not what I'd think of
> as typical Yoshioka group work. It can be tough to
> attribute a lot of the unsigned later menuki to a
> specific group.
>
> Jim

> Edo
> or Meiji.
>
> Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Unusual Frog / Toad Menuki
messages.msgSnippet: Jim - Had to take a look at my toads to compare. These are as you said, much better quality and they do not have the full face pose represented but
messages.messageBody:
Jim -

Had to take a look at my "toads" to compare. These are as you said, much better quality and they do not have the "full face" pose represented but instead, side views with the primary menuki "toad" looking away, so you get a nice back and back-of-head view. A much more pleasant pair than this site pair in my opinion. Love them! Thanks...made me think of our mutual friend, Bill.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, December 17, 2003 5:57 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Unusual Frog / Toad Menuki


Curran,
For what it's worth I used to have a pair of menuki in exactly that "pose" that were signed on the edge Yoshioka Inabanosuke. They were better quality than these appear to be, and were not what I'd think of as typical Yoshioka group work. It can be tough to attribute a lot of the unsigned later menuki to a specific group.

Jim




Groups-

Came across these unusual menuki. Figured it might
interest some others.

http://www.l-wise.co.jp/sword/sdata24/clk259b.htm

Any chance anyone can attribute this ugly duo to any
specific school? I'm assuming they are late late Edo
or Meiji.

Curran

messages.messageBody:
Curran,
For what it's worth I used to have a pair of menuki in exactly that "pose" that were signed on the edge Yoshioka Inabanosuke. They were better quality than these appear to be, and were not what I'd think of as typical Yoshioka group work. It can be tough to attribute a lot of the unsigned later menuki to a specific group.

Jim

interest some others.

http://www.l-wise.co.jp/sword/sdata24/clk259b.htm

Any chance anyone can attribute this ugly duo to any
specific school? I'm assuming they are late late Edo
or Meiji.

Curran
